pr_title: [JENKINS-64423, JENKINS-46618] Resolve all core caused startup Illegal reflective access warnings

timeline.message: Resolve all core caused Illegal reflective access warnings

timeline.bodyText:
wondering if this ClassLoaderReflectionToolkit could be removed, assuming everything goes through AntWithFindResourceClassLoader then this line never gets called.
(from my minimal plugin set in my test Jenkins this assumption is always true)
any thoughts? this comment applies throughout the PR
timeline.author: timja

replies.bodyText: Not sure. May apply in JenkinsRule under exotic conditions?
replies.author: jglick

replies.bodyText:
it does seem to apply in JenkinsRule :(, see my happiness in my commit message here:
555e516
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText: 🤷‍♂️ if you can verify that only AntWithFindResourceClassLoader is ever used at this point, including in various test harnesses, we could probably simplify a bunch of code, and put in some assertions.
replies.author: jglick

replies.bodyText: Well I can verify at runtime it's fine, but in tests (at least AssetManagerTest) it's not fine, it runs with a classloader built into the JDK, AppClassLoader I think.
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText: So sounds like we still need ClassLoaderReflectionToolkit at least for now.
replies.author: jglick

timeline.bodyText:
this call seems to just check if the class is null?

If I add a null check IDE tell's me that it's impossible for it to be null at this point.
Removing this check doesn't break any tests
timeline.author: timja

replies.author: jglick

replies.bodyText: Maybe this became obsolete somehow in 11, but still appears to do something real in 8, so suggest reverting or calling this only on 8.
replies.author: jglick

replies.bodyText:
The code that called this is removed in java 9, https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8057777
I'm not sure if it was doing something in 8 or not, the code was removed because it wasn't doing anything but it doesn't say why, it couldn't been something in 9 that meant it wasn't used any more.
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText:
I can't seem to see where the definition of resolveClass0 lies to confirm no side-effects. It seems difficult to confirm that removing this is safe.

it couldn't been something in 9 that meant it wasn't used any more.

How did you arrive at this conclusion?
Even if that is the case there is a possibility it was removed in a jdk8 update but which update exactly, there might be breakages on systems with older versions of jdk8 possibly.
replies.author: res0nance

replies.bodyText:
I read the code, but the openjdk repo is only tagged up to v120 or so of java 8.
the code definitely does nothing on 9.
If people think it’s still worth keeping I can re-add it but only for java 8
replies.author: timja
jglick

timeline.bodyText: changes in this class are mostly lazy initialisation, to stop warnings if the code isn't used, possible this class could be deprecated as I can't see anything that requires it, but I've left fallbacks in that call this code for extra safety
timeline.author: timja

timeline.bodyText: To avoid duplication, maybe revert all these changes at call sites, and encode the desired nonreflective behavior into ClassLoaderReflectionToolkit? (For clarity, could introduce an interface implemented by AntWithFindResourceClassLoader which defines the required methods.)
timeline.author: jglick

replies.bodyText: yup was thinking about that, the only reason I didn't do that was I was looking to see if we could retire it completely
replies.author: timja

timeline.bodyText: Not thread-safe. You could either make this and similar methods synchonized, or use a private static nested holder class with final variables to implement lazy initialization (which would make for a simpler patch overall I guess).
timeline.author: jglick

replies.bodyText:
second method sounds good 👍
thanks I was worried about that bit
replies.author: timja

timeline.bodyText: Prefer to revert unnecessary hunks to keep the diff minimal.
timeline.author: jglick
jglick
jglick
jglick
jglick
jglick
jglick

timeline.bodyText: Is this supposed to be a class name? If so, use @link or (if 9+) @code. Or some other code name? @code. Otherwise, avoid CamelCase.
timeline.author: jglick

timeline.bodyText: Wonder why these are not using invoke.
timeline.author: jglick

replies.bodyText: hmm isn't it using invoke? or do you mean something else?
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText: I meant ClassLoaderReflectionToolkit.invoke rather than Method.invoke.

replies.bodyText: why? the try catch was removed so indentation changed
